posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
Hmmm...interesting!

The EDR is not really a problem - Divine damage and Positive damage go through it (but, that is environment dependent).  Otherwise, not bad.  Good protection!  I guess it really depends on what is available UMD wise in the environment as to what can be done about damage.

AC is really low.  I might be able to get you with a Stun fist, and definitely with a Quivering Palm, I think.  That fort save is not that high.

You have no Uncanny Dodge.

So if I am HiPSing...and you can't see or notice me...I believe that tumble AC is gone as well (flat-footed).  I suppose you could just do continual Whirlwinds (though with ED...it will miss).

That AB is nice.  With the right weapon, it will probably hit AC 75 (this AC is item dependent, but conforms to a +5 environment aka WoG).  With a 49 base AB, you should be able to get into hitting range, and crit range as well.  I don't know about the second attack at -5 AB, however.  That would put your base AB at 44.

Note that Greatsword does not have a really good crit range...you will probably want a keen one.

You have a problem, tho.

I sneak (you can't see me - unless there is true TS available ;) ) I hit, run.  Monk speed is so fast, you will not be able to really do anything about the hit and run - and the first successful attack will miss, anyway (ED).  Note that my build has HiPS.  Now, in an environment where HiPS is not nerfed, or on a timer (and no true TS), that means HiPS spamming.  Your build will not hit anything as it continually loses "focus".

IF you roll a 1 - you will get paralyzed (Ass Death Attack)...so you will need some immunity to that.

I can do this indefinitely, so...you will roll a 1.  No immunity...you are dead.

If I make a mistake, you might get me.  Bad luck for me.

When it comes to UMD - any buffs I can blow off with pretty much impunity from a distance, because you cannot close the distance.  I might just decide to UMD you from a distance.  You have no spell immunity, and your Will saves are abysmal.

Remember, my build does not really rely on magic at all (in buff form).  It benefits greatly from magic items, yes.  But magic buffs, if it has the right magical items, it does not need - though both DP and PnP TT are very helpful, of course (and all the other AB raising buffs).

It is hard to dispell what one cannot see, however.  Or target (HiPS). 

Your spot is way too low.  And that Wis...your build will require real TS.  A boatload of immunities to protect from UMD scroll/wand/x against that Will save.  One Bigby will end your day. 

Interesting would be a Timestop duel (assuming it is available for UMD).
character attacking from shadows will always start first as his target cannot even see him
This lasts for the 1st round. 

So attacking, breaking off, HiPS, run...wait.

Rinse, repeat.

Your build will need real TS to succeed at melee.  Ranged, it is a whole different contest.  Now, I can stay away from you until you run out of real TS uses, unless you have it on an item permanently.  You will need this to avoid getting nailed by ranged UMD spells.

In fact, your builds greatest weakness is spells.

But let us consider this with just the mundane items...hehe.

I am going to HiPS you to death.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
Monk35/SD5 (and UMD variants) is one of the best defensive builds in NWN, period. Across every server I've played on I have never seen a PvP build that can RELIABLY kill a Monk/SD in 1v1 open world PvP. In a 1v1 duel situation where the builds are forced to fight this changes, but as long as the Monk/SD can run away almost all 1v1 fights will end in either a Monk/SD win or a draw.

I think webshaman1 has already pointed out most of the key issues this build will have in a 1v1 duel situation. Your build has high AB, high damage, 9/- Physical DR and Dev Crit, but without vanilla True Seeing it can't reliably compete with HiPS spamming. Even if you rebuilt it as a spotter elf my money would still be on the Monk/SD.

posts.content:
I have laid down the gauntlet to our dear WebShaman.

Web believes our build, whilst formidable, will be beaten by Nightshade (provided our build doesn't start off with a lucky dev crit).

It is time for others to step up to the plate and see who can defeat Nightshade :)

This is not the time for fence sitting. 

Get at that WebShaman, the elite builders of the ECB!

Edit: 
Uncanny dodge can be easily added by going a Fighter 12 / Rogue 3 / WM 25 level split, at the cost of 1 AB.

Also looks I was ninja'ed by Yunim. 
In terms of environment, I agree with Yunim here that an open space Nightshade can run, but in a locked space, Nightshade will struggle. 

Put Nightslayer in a 2x2m locked cage with Nightshade, I believe Nightshade has no chance against this 600-840hp EDR III Base AB 49 massive crit monster. 
Nightshade can tickle the Nightslayer with his divine damage gloves for 5 damage, but one dev crit = bye bye.

Further edit:
@webshaman1 brings up death attack, but in an environment where freedom is available on items, equip one of those, and death attack is irrelevant.

I believe Web's suggestion that UMD is this builds weakness is correct and really the way Nightshade would (and should) deal with Nightslayer.
My favored solution for Nightshade to deal with Nightslayer would be Haste -> Time Stop -> Mords -> Bigby's.

However if Nightslayer gets the first attack in, he should 
1. Equip an item with True Seeing (they exist in WoG, I have 3 of them amongst my characters) 
2. Haste -> Time Stop -> Potion of True Strike (instant AB +75) -> Attack -> Time Stop -> Potion True Strike -> Attack [continue sequence] until Devastating Critical is landed. 

I think much depends on who gets the first Time Stop scroll off.

It is much easier for Nightshade once that Bigby's lands however, Nightslayer does not have that luxury to seriously use Bigby's against Nightshade.

The item with True Seeing has limitations including an abysmal AC but would be, in my view, the best way to deal with the HiPS in Nightshade's arsenal. 

I didn't go Scimitar based on feedback from Yogmister, he felt that a big two handed sword was necessary to penetrate any possible DR belts Nightslayer might have equipped, this was what scared him most when playing this Epic Dodging Monk/SD/UMD'er. 

Nightshade might save a few dev crits and have a greater swordman's belt equipped, landing huge critical hit damage (x3) with two handed weaponmaster was felt to be the way to go, even if Dev crit doesn't occur, HP decimation will, finally ending the terror of Nightshade on the WoG PW server.

Further Edit 2:
One other thought. Spell resistance on items. I usually ignore this, but would this be useful against Bigby's scrolls? Is this property lowerable with Mords/Breaches? Something I will want to read up on.

Further Edit 3:
And I will partially answer my question. Maybe. 

Highest SR in items is 32. Bigby's 9 scrolls have CL 20. 

Spell resistance check = d20 + caster level + spell penetration  vs. SR
20 + d20 vs 32
 = need to roll 12 or more to equal or beat SR which leads to spell succeeding. 

So the Nightslayer will need to equip a high SR item to defeat Nightshade.

One other comment on HiPS

In detect mode, a player will detect stealth 5 times / second with 1d20 rolls + spot score vs hide.
In normal mode a player will detect stealth 5 times / second with 1d10 rolls + spot score vs hide.
On WoG HiPS is once every 6 seconds.
Therefore detecting stealth is checked 30 times more often than one can HiPS, in a PvP situation in WoG.

Boosting that spot score within 10-20 of Nightshade's Hide score will basically mean Nightshade is detected by Nightslayer and HiPS may be ineffective.
I can boost spot a little higher by doing a F12/R3/WM25 at the cost of 1 AB, and dropping a little UMD, search, even the high value set trap/disable trap points.
The highest base modified Spot score is going to be 42, which could be boosted by items (ie Watchman's Helm) meaning that a True Sight item might not be completely essential, to defeat Nightshade's HiPS.

posts.content:
The problem with your detect scenario is that HiPS causes you to drop out of combat, regardless of whether you make the check or not.

So you need vanilla TS.

On WoG, there is a set of +5 Robes with vanilla TS.  My Nightshade wears them (where needed).

I will remind you that my build has Shadow Daze :
Once per day the shadowdancer may inflict an illusory daze upon a target. This daze lasts for 5 rounds.
Use: selected
Notes Edit
  • Added in the expansion packs.
  • This feat allows a will saving throw to negate the effect, with a DC of 10 + dexterity modifier + shadowdancer level.
  • This ability can be used at long (40 meters) range.
This targets your weak Will save with a very powerful DC Daze that will last 5 rounds.  This then brings up Quivering Palm
If the character makes a successful attack after activating the ability, the target must make a fortitude save (DC 10 + half the monk's character level + the monk's wisdom modifier) or die.
Even though Fort is your high save, the DC is going to be 10+17+2~3.  That is a DC of ~30.  Your Fort is 24.  I got an ok chance to nail you.

As for you going first, it is not going to happen.  Initiative (as it is figured in NWN) is Dex based.

Unless you get a surprise round (and the opposite is realistically true), you will almost never beat my initiative roll.
The roll is a d20 plus the character's dexterity modifier, plus bonuses from feats.
Your Dex of 13 is...low.  +1 modifier.  Nightshade's Dex is really high.  Like, sky high.  All points in Dex.  Your build has no bonuses from feats.

We could decide to do this in a +5 item environment.  You want to confine the space - just make it a 1x1 cm square...hehe, just kidding!  You are trying to "move the goal posts" to your build's overwhelming advantage!  Just make it easier on yourself, and say the Nightshade has no legs and can't move.

Even in a PnP arena, there is more space than 2x2.  I don't think you realize how fast a high level Monk really moves...

Even if your build had vanilla TS, it is extremely vulnerable to Nightshade's ranged attacks (which are Dex based, and guess who is a Dex based build?)  One nice heavy xbow...ouch!  True, that EDR of +9 will tank most of it (unless the bolts also have elemental/divine/Pos/Neg damage).  Crits will HURT!  And as your build has no way to actually catch Nightshade, she can kite you all day.

Down to the spell challenge.

Basically, who gets off the Timestop first?  Nightshade (higher initiative means she goes first) assuming that is what we are doing (in any environment where Timestop is available in UMD form, is going to be advantageous to both as UMD users, so only Initiative is going to matter here).

As your build has a weak Will save...any hand spells targeting you that affect Will is going to be a huge threat.  In fact, any spell that targets your weak Will save is going to be a threat.

I don't consider your Nightslayer to be a slayer at all.  It will only have a chance under select conditions that are advantageous to the build and disadvantageous to the Nightshade build.  That is not a condition of fairness.

Perhaps another Nightshade? 😂

To kill Nightshade, you need Nightshade!

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
There are some issues with the offence of a Monk/SD but if properly built the defences are amazing. The build isn't completely invincible but most of the tactics that will work against it are either banned on PvP servers or are unreliable. It also depends on the size of the arena and whether the Monk/SD is actively trying to kill your build or just survive.
Making a build that a Monk/SD will struggle to kill isn't too hard, making a build that can reliably kill a Monk/SD is.

Quivering Palm can only be used on lower level targets so in a 40 vs 40 PvP battle it won't work.
Death Attack actually isn't a problem for this build since you can spam WWA to prevent the paralysis roll. However, if you spam WWA then you won't be able to attack when the Monk/SD hits you and HiPS spam will gradually kill you before you can even land a hit.
Regarding 32 SR, a Mords will reduce that to 22 SR at which point a Bigby9 scroll will have a 95% chance of beating your SR. If you have Freedom or Mind Spell Immunity and Mords scrolls then that will be less of a concern, but those buffs will have to be on items since a Mords will dispel them otherwise.

I assume that you have never faced a HiPS build played by a competent player in PvP before? With +12 DEX a Monk/SD will have around 60 Hide/MS which can be beaten pretty easily by a dedicated spotter (assuming that there are an equal amount of Hide items and Spot items), but only a dedicated spotter can reliably spot a HiPSer. If you are not an elf spotter or if you do not have vanilla True Seeing then you will not touch a properly built HiPSer, even with a 6 second HiPS timer. If the HiPS timer was 2 or 3 rounds then you might have a chance, but due to how detect works you won't be able to spot a HiPSer with this build.

Any decent melee build with access to Mords, vanilla Time Stop, and vanilla True Seeing will be able to kill it.
Fairly self-explanatory, True Seeing to prevent hiding in HiPS, Mords to dispel GSanc, Time Stop to stop time. Without True Seeing the Monk/SD can HiPS as soon as you start reading the scroll and you will struggle to detect them. This is less of an issue with a melee spotter, a properly built spotter should be able to detect the Monk/SD. Without Mords you can't dispel Gsanc, so you will either need to get lucky catching the Monk/SD out of GSanc or carry enough scrolls to keep time stopped until GSanc runs out. Without Time Stop this tactic is worthless. Since this is PvP the Monk/SD also has access to this tactic so it's not exactly reliable. Note that you can't simultaneously spam Time Stop scrolls and melee without messing up your timing, as soon as the first Time Stop is over the Monk/SD will be able to Time Stop you before you can use another scroll. Whoever casts Time Stop first wins, for obvious reasons this would not be a valid tactic on a balanced PvP server.
Example builds: Cler28/Bard2/RDD10, Figh14/WM25/Bard1, Figh16/WM7/Wiz17.

Attacking from stealth can potentially work if you get very lucky or are fighting in a small area.
This won't work if vanilla True Seeing is available or if the Monk/SD is able to run away. If the Monk/SD runs right past you while you are in stealth and you can click them before they zoom off you might be able to get 1 flurry in, if you can get past the high AC, 50% concealment, and Epic Dodge. Overall, not very reliable but it might work on a non-elf Monk/SD in an enclosed area.
Example build: Rog13/Rang26/SD1.

Stacking 10 epic traps on one spot and luring the Monk/SD over them can work.
You have to stack enough traps for a OHK or it can just run away and heal. If the Monk/SD knows that you are using this tactic then there are multiple ways for them to disrupt it so it's still not a reliable tactic. It might work a few times but once the Monk/SD knows what you are doing and adapts to it you will have to get lucky to kill them.
Example build: Rog19/Bard5/PM16.

A high caster level mage with ESPen can potentially work.
A pure Sorc40 or Wiz40 with ESPen has a 30% chance (potentially 20% chance) of beating the SR of a Monk35/SD5 and a 35% chance of beating the SR of a UMD variant. 38 or 39 caster levels are acceptable but I would avoid going below that, even though it means forfeiting 3 monk levels. You will need to have vanilla True Seeing or be an elf spotter in order to actually target the Monk/SD. Bigby6 is the only useful disabling spell against a Monk/SD and you will have to get past both SR and mantles in order to land it. If vanilla Time Stop is availably then alternating between Time Stop and nuke spells can work too. If the Monk/SD approaches in GSanc then you won't have any idea of where they are until they breach your shields and KD spam you to death.
If the Monk/SD has access to knockdown immunity, you lose. If you run out of Bigby6, you lose. If you don't have vanilla True Seeing or are not a dedicated spotter, you lose. If the area has plenty of corners that can be used to break your LoS, you lose. If you neglect discipline and fortitude, you lose.
This still isn't a reliable victory but it's probably your best option.
Example builds: Sorc38/Pal1/Monk1, Sorc40, Wiz39/Rang1.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
RE HiPS
I speak specifically regarding the 6 second timer is on WoG and nothing else.

If you look at the NWN detect article you will notice a player checks spot/stealth 5 checks / second 
This is in contrast with enemies/NPCs which check stealth much less frequently.

5 checks / second x 6 seconds = 30 checks per HiPS attempt.
If spot is 50 vs 60 (I don't believe Web's build goes that high, but I am happy to be corrected because Web hasn't posted it yet) with 1d10 die and a 9 or 10 is needed to spot. (without detect mode)
10% chance to detect per check. 90% not to detect.
Chance for Nightshade to successfully HiPS and remain unspotted for those 6 seconds = 34%.
Add more spot your chances go up.
But vanilla true seeing looks more reliable so I will ditch that idea.

Web goes ISR heavy, I believe the SR goes to 66 to counter epic spell pen casters (5% chance of successfully casting a spell). Casters are not really the solution to Nightshade.

The epic trap idea sounds sensible, and perhaps a large stack of epic frost traps (which don't take into account evasion) would do the trick. I don't believe Nightshade has a lot of search to ever get a search roll within 45.

Some sort of 600 HP dev crit high AB EDR III monster with a greater brawlers belt / freedom / true seeing was the best I can come up with, lock Nightshade in a 2m x 2m cage, or Time Stop/True Strike cheese and get that dev crit or damage him sufficiently that he finally falls. 

An archer was interesting and Yogmister7 thought that could work, With deflect arrows and epic dodge two arrows are going to miss/round. This uses up the first flurry assuming both arrows were going to hit.  Then an AA might have a base AB 50+ with rapid shot/haste have 6 APR, but the dev crit range is 19-20 (or 18-20 with a keen bow). Plus Nightshade can just run around a corner after that first flurry, then get the Bigby's ready.

The build is a Monk34/SD5/Ass1 with Epic Dodge and high SR. I don't believe that webshaman1's specific build has been posted online but there are very few ways to make a decent Monk/SD so it's not hard to guess  what the build could be.

You're assuming that a Monk/SD will HiPS and then walk towards you in stealth mode to attack you. That might be how you use it in PvM and that might be how NPCs use it, but that is not how PvP HiPSers use HiPS. It is also why a 1 round HiPS timer does not matter at all to a competent player in PvP. Immediately after they HiPS you will have an action cancel, triggering this cancel is the key use of HiPS in PvP.
HiPS actually works better on PCs than NPCs because of how often PCs detect. I have made 127 Spot elf builds that will sometimes lose track of 115ish Hide characters due to how detect works. Even if you have 80 Spot and are fighting a 60 Hide HiPSer, if you're not an elf it won't matter. If you don't have Keen Senses and are not in detect mode then your Spot is halved when rolling, not even 80 Spot will help you.
If a HiPSer attacks you you will have a -10 Spot modifier even if you don't fight back. The HiPSer will then disengage straight after the first flurry and run away. This negative modifier will last for 1 round, when the HiPSer is free to HiPS again. If the HiPSer is smart then they will also use summons such as Elemental Swarm to force you into combat even after they have disengaged. Elf helps here since they are in constant detect mode and so combat has less of an effect, although they will still have a -10 Spot modifier. A non-elf without vanilla True Seeing is not able to compete with a competently built and played HiPSer. If you don't build to fight a HiPSer you will lose, that's part of what makes the feat so OP and is why it gets nerfed on so many servers.

Archers won't work since they have to deal with high AC, Epic Dodge, Deflect Arrows, 50% concealment, and UMD. You can build for detect or have vanilla True Seeing, but unless you're a Monk/AA the Monk/SD will be able to hit you in melee without HiPS spamming. A Monk/SD can use HiPS to cancel your attacks, run in IExp to get into melee range, and then use melee or UMD to finish the archer off. A Monk/AA is the best option since they have the AC to semi-tank the Monk/SDs AB but ultimately the Monk/SD can still win by (ab)using UMD.

You can have 67 SR and you can have Epic Dodge but you can't have both at the same time. A Monk35/SD5 will have 61 SR if it takes Armor Skin or 63 SR if it focuses on SR. A Monk34/SD5/Ass1 or Monk34/SD5/Rog1 will have 60 SR. A Sorc39/Pal1 with ESPen will have a 30% chance of beating the SR of a Monk34/SD5/Ass1. If vanilla True Seeing is available then that's probably your best bet against a Monk/SD in an enclosed area, although it's still not a reliable counter for reasons given above.
